prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HIgh frequency observations of the 13C17O and 13C18O J=6-5 lines in IRAS16342

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator is configured in spectral mode in dual polarization. Three spectral windows have been defined in order to minimize the observing time by performing simultaneous observations when possible. In the first and second windows the 13C18O and 13C17O J=6-5 spectral lines are selected (full fraction). In the third window the continuum setup is defined (full fraction). We have selected in the line setups a higher spectral resolution (0.5 km/s) than the 5 km/s resolution used in the calculation of the sensitivity because we plan to channel average to increase the SNR and to have a similar resolution as in our Herschel data. For the continuum setup we have selected the widest possible configuration, 870 km/s (2 GHz) with a resolution of 14.5 km/s (31.25 MHz).

HST Images of IRAS 16342 shows that the region where the CO emission at high frequency is supposed to arise, should be of about 2 arcsec from the central source. A minimum of 0.2 arcsec should be sufficient to resolve any possible molecular structures.

We plan to study the J=6-5 transition of the 13C17O and 13C18O in IRAS 16342-3814. Our calculations for the proposed sensitivity are based in our Herschel spectra of the 13C17O line (the weakest line detected). Peak intensities of 0.011 K (~ 4 Jy) are measured for the 40 arcsec beam of Herschel. For ALMA, this translates into 40 mJy, a sensitivity of 8 mJy for a 5-sigma detection. Also, the line widths measured with Herschel is ~ 50 km/s. From previous studies of the molecular gas in pPNe, we need a spectral resolution of 5 km/s to be able to study the kinematics of the gas throughout the nebula (outer envelope, bipolar outflow and other possible molecular components).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High frequency observations of the C18O, C17O and 13CO J=6-5 lines in IRAS16342

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator is configured in spectral mode in dual polarization. Four spectral windows have been defined in order to minimize the observing time by performing simultaneous observations when possible. In the spectral lines and continuum a full fraction is selected. We have selected in the line setups a higher spectral resolution (0.5 km/s) than the 5 km/s resolution used in the calculation of the sensitivity because we plan to channel average to increase the SNR and to have a similar resolution as in our Herschel data. For the continuum setup we have selected the widest possible configuration, 830 km/s (2 GHz) with a resolution of 14.5 km/s (31.25 MHz).

HST Images of IRAS 16342 shows that the region where the CO emission at high frequency is supposed to arise, should be of about 2 arcsec from the central source. A minimum of 0.2 arcsec should be sufficient to resolve any possible molecular structures.

We plan to study the J=6-5 transition of the C18O, 13CO and C17O in IRAS 16342-3814. Our calculations for the proposed sensitivity are based in our Herschel spectra. Based in the H2O line detections, we derive an isotopic ratio 16O/17O of ~ 2 (in the worst case) and therefore we assume a C17O(6-5) peak intensity of 0.02 K (7 Jy) for the 31 arcsec beam of Herschel. For ALMA, this translates into 70 mJy, a sensitivity of 14 mJy for a 5-sigma detection. Also, the line widths measured with Herschel is ~ 50 km/s. From previous studies of the molecular gas in pPNe, we need a spectral resolution of 5 km/s to be able to study the kinematics of the gas throughout the nebula (outer envelope, bipolar outflow and other possible molecular components).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High frequency observations of the 12CO J=6-5 line in IRAS16342

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator is configured in spectral mode in dual polarization. Three spectral windows have been defined in order to minimize the observing time by performing simultaneous observations when possible. In the first and second windows the C17O and 12CO J=6-5 spectral lines are selected (1/2 fraction). In the third window the continuum setup is defined (full fraction). We have selected in the line setups a higher spectral resolution (0.4 km/s) than the 5 km/s resolution used in the calculation of the sensitivity because we plan to channel average to increase the SNR and to have a similar resolution as in our Herschel data. For the continuum setup we have selected the widest possible configuration, 833 km/s (2 GHz) with a resolution of 14 km/s (31.25 MHz).

HST Images of IRAS 16342 shows that the region where the CO emission at high frequency is supposed to arise, should be of about 2 arcsec from the central source. A minimum of 0.2 arcsec should be sufficient to resolve any possible molecular structures.

We plan to study the J=6-5 transition of the C17O ans 12CO in IRAS 16342-3814. Our calculations for the proposed sensitivity are based in our Herschel spectra and are similar to those in setup 2. Based in the H2O line detections, we derive an isotopic ratio 16O/17O of ~ 2 (in the worst case) and therefore we assume a C17O(6-5) peak intensity of 0.02 K (7 Jy) for the 31 arcsec beam of Herschel. For ALMA, this translates into 70 mJy, a sensitivity of 14 mJy for a 5-sigma detection. Also, the line widths measured with Herschel is ~ 50 km/s. From previous studies of the molecular gas in pPNe, we need a spectral resolution of 5 km/s to be able to study the kinematics of the gas throughout the nebula (outer envelope, bipolar outflow and other possible molecular components). We note that the C17O line is also observed in setup 2 and that we have included it in this setup because it can be simultaneously observed with the 12CO(6-5) line without adding observing time.

The correlator is configured in spectral mode in dual polarization. Four spectral windows have been defined in order to minimize the observing time by performing simultaneous observations when possible. In all the basebands full fraction is defined. We have selected in the line setups a higher spectral resolution (0.4 km/s) than the 5 km/s resolution used in the calculation of the sensitivity because we plan to channel average to increase the SNR. For the continuum setup we have selected the widest possible configuration, 850 km/s (2 GHz) with a resolution of 0.4 km/s.

HST Images of IRAS 16342 shows that the region where the CO emission is supposed to arise, should be of about 2 arcsec from the central source. A minimum of 0.2 arcsec should be sufficient to resolve any possible molecular structures.

We plan to study the J=3-2 transition of the 12CO and 13CO in IRAS 16342-3814. Our calculations for the proposed sensitivity are based in previous observations of the 12CO(3-2) performed by Imai et al. (2009). We assume a peak intensity of 0.033 K (1.6 Jy) for the 22 arcsec beam of ASTE. For the ALMA desired beam, this translates into aprox. 15 mJy, and therefore for a 5-sigma detection we need a sensitivity of about 3 mJy (or 0.8 K). Also, the line widths are ~ 80 km/s. From previous studies of the molecular gas in pPNe, we need a spectral resolution of 5 km/s to be able to study the kinematics of the gas throughout the nebula (outer envelope, bipolar outflow and other possible molecular components).

The correlator is configured in spectral mode in dual polarization. Four spectral windows have been defined in order to minimize the observing time by performing simultaneous observations when possible. In all the basebands full fraction is defined. We have selected in the line setups a higher spectral resolution (0.4 km/s) than the 5 km/s resolution used in the calculation of the sensitivity because we plan to channel average to increase the SNR. For the continuum setup we have selected the widest possible configuration, 1600 km/s with a resolution of 28 km/s.

HST Images of IRAS 16342 shows that the region where the CO emission is supposed to arise, should be of about 2 arcsec from the central source. A minimum of 0.2 arcsec should be sufficient to resolve any possible molecular structures.

We plan to study the J=3-2 transition of the C17O in IRAS 16342-3814. Our calculations for the proposed sensitivity are similar to those used for the 12CO and 13CO J=3-2, that is for a 5-sigma detection we need a sensitivity of about 3 mJy. We also use the same line width and velocity resolution: ~ 80 km/s and 5 km/s, to be able to study the kinematics of the gas throughout the nebula.

The correlator is configured in spectral mode in dual polarization. Four spectral windows have been defined in order to minimize the observing time by performing simultaneous observations when possible. In all the basebands full fraction is defined. We have selected in the line setups a higher spectral resolution (0.3-0.5 km/s) than the 5 km/s resolution used in the calculation of the sensitivity because we plan to channel average to increase the SNR. For the continuum setup we have selected the widest possible configuration, 450 km/s with a resolution of 0.5 km/s.

HST Images of IRAS 16342 shows that the region where the CO emission is supposed to arise, should be of about 2 arcsec from the central source. A minimum of 0.2 arcsec should be sufficient to resolve any possible molecular structures.

We plan to study the J=3-2 transition of the C18O and 13C18O in IRAS 16342-3814. Our calculations for the proposed sensitivity are similar to those used for the 12CO and 13CO J=3-2, that is for a 5-sigma detection we need a sensitivity of about 3 mJy. We also use the same line width and velocity resolution: ~ 80 km/s and 5 km/s, to be able to study the kinematics of the gas throughout the nebula.

The correlator is configured in spectral mode in dual polarization. Four spectral windows have been defined in order to minimize the observing time by performing simultaneous observations when possible. In all the basebands full fraction is defined. We have selected in the line setups a higher spectral resolution (0.5 km/s) than the 5 km/s resolution used in the calculation of the sensitivity because we plan to channel average to increase the SNR. For the continuum setup we have selected the widest possible configuration, 1700 km/s with a resolution of 29 km/s.

HST Images of IRAS 16342 shows that the region where the CO emission is supposed to arise, should be of about 2 arcsec from the central source. A minimum of 0.2 arcsec should be sufficient to resolve any possible molecular structures.

We plan to study the J=3-2 transition of the 13C17O in IRAS 16342-3814. Our calculations for the proposed sensitivity are similar to those used for the 12CO and 13CO J=3-2, that is for a 5-sigma detection we need a sensitivity of about 3 mJy. We also use the same line width and velocity resolution: ~ 80 km/s and 5 km/s, to be able to study the kinematics of the gas throughout the nebula.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the most intriguing aspects of the evolution of intermediate mass stars is how they evolve to form asymmetric Planetary Nebulae. After the end of the AGB, fast and highly bipolar post-AGB flows collide with the low-velocity and spherical circumstellar envelopes of the former AGB star. This interaction lasts only about 100 yr. To gain insight into this subject we need to study the earliest post-AGB sources known; the water fountains (WFs). These are OH/IR sources that display H2O maser emission over an unusual wide velocity range, which trace very fast bipolar outflows, with kinematic ages as short as 40-100 yr. WFs are not well known since ground-based observations have been, in most cases, unsuccessful due to severe interstellar contamination. However, we successfully detected with Herschel high-J CO and H2O lines in IRAS16342-3814, where we found a very low 12CO/13CO line intensity ratio and a high abundance of the rare isotopomers 13CO, H2-17O and H2-18O. We propose to study the J=3-2 and J=6-5 CO lines using ALMA, to characterize the excitation of the molecular gas and identify the hottest and most recently ejected molecular gas in the WF IRAS16342.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronomico Nacional

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronomico Nacional
